oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Earl Thomas Conley Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Earl Thomas Conley (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Earl Thomas Conley; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Earl Thomas Conley talks about being born in Portsmith, Ohio and being the third child of eight -- (00:35) Conley talks about his father working on steam engines and losing his job for fifteen years causing his alcoholism -- (01:10) Conley talks about the lack of money in his home and his families ability to repurpose -- (03:05) Conley talks about Hank Williams and his father's musical talents -- (03:40) Conley talks about listening to the Opry while his family drank -- (04:39) Conley talks about Elvis, among others, and following the progression of popular music -- (05:51) Conley talks about his record collection and his Victrola -- (06:27) Conley talks about his uncle and how he taught Conley music before being disfigured -- (07:20) Conley talks about joining the military and the fellow soldiers he would listen to George Jones music with -- (08:16) Collie and Conley talk about his inability to play and his high school popular music influences -- (09:24) Conley talks about seeing Earnest Tubb and Jan Howard while in Germany and his fellow solider introducing him to new music -- (10:09) Conley reflects on imitating styles and how influences hurt recording work -- (10:39) Conley talks about artistic inclinations before song writing -- (11:26) Conley talks about working in a steel mill, listening to Charlie Pride, and beginning to song write -- (12:20) Conley speaks on getting introduced to a recording studio through his uncle -- (13:05) Conley's studio development and work history is discussed -- (13:56) Conley talks about Meryl Streep and the process of "Smokey Mountain Memories" is discussed -- (15:00) Conley talks about attempting to avoid melody plagiarism by using minor cords -- (15:54) Conley talks about his growing popularity as a song writer and how his personal artistic success progressed -- (17:20) Conley talks about how he battled between being unique and playable -- (18:05) Collie and Conley discuss the use of studios with recording -- (19:13) Conley talks about meeting up with Tommy Brassfield -- (19:41) Conley talks about moving to Nashville in 1974 and recording in bunches -- (20:20) Conley talks about the importance of timing -- (21:36) Conley and Collie discuss Conley's ascension to popularity and being turned down by Warner Brothers for an entire album -- (22:55) "Middle Age Madness" and "Middle Age Crazy" are discussed based on a similarity of thought process -- (24:01) Conley talks about working on a Freddie Hart album and releasing "Silent Treatment" in the midst of other works and how it lead to a Sunburnt Records deal - (25:29) Collie and Conley talks about his growing career and his ideas on being a mainstream artist -- (28:55) Collie and Conley discuss the unique niche that describes Conley's fan group -- (29:35) Conley reiterates his success confirming his career path -- (30:35) Conley talks about how his beard was a way of hiding himself for over ten years -- (31:29) Conley tells Collie about his greatest satisfaction coming from his artistic achievements and having a grand-daughter
